headline: Three things the Trump admin. can do to help business: BofA CEO
summary: Markets have been pricing in optimism on what a Trump administration can do for businesses. Bank of America CEO, Brian Moynihan told Yahoo Finance Executive Editor Brian Sozzi at Yahoo Finance Invest what he thinks a Trump administration can do to unleash the power of business. Moynihan highlighted the need to enhance what makes America great, calling it “the place to invest on a global basis.” However, Moynihan noting key areas that need some work. First, the Trump administration handling government spending— Moynihan saying “they have to think about how to get that in better balance.” The Bank of America CEO also brining into focus the need to handle tax laws and solve housing issues. Moynihan saying “if you try and solve housing, you've got to build more housing— and the way you're going to build more housing is to figure out how to create the incentives for communities to permit more activity.” To see every interview from Yahoo Finance Invest, click here. See the full interview with Brian Moynihan here. This post was written by Ivana Freitas.

headline: Fed Chair Powell has done a good job: Bank of America CEO Moynihan
summary: Questions linger on the possibility of the Federal Reserve’s independence being challenged under the administration of President-elect Trump. Bank of America CEO, Brian Moynihan chimed in on his views on the control system around the Fed during an interview with Yahoo Finance Executive Editor Brian Sozzi at Yahoo Finance Invest. Moynihan says that an “independent central bank is a good place to be.” When asked about the job Fed Chair Jerome Powell has done thus far, Moynihan voiced his approval of Powell’s performance, saying "he has done a good job working through the system." He admits the Fed was late in addressing rising inflation, but he notes that the situation at the time was "unprecedented." To see every interview from Yahoo Finance Invest, click here. See the full interview with Brian Moynihan here. This post was written by Ivana Freitas.

headline: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan on Trump, the Fed, & regulation
summary: At the Yahoo Finance Invest conference, Bank of America (BAC) Chairman and CEO Brian Moynihan tells Yahoo Finance executive editor Brian Sozzi the banking industry has shown “resiliency” following the regional banking crisis and would welcome changes to regulation. “I think our job as an industry is to make sure that we do it in a way that is fair in all aspects. Fair to the companies, so they can support the economy… Fair to the consumers, fair to the investors and fair to the American economy. And also at the end of the day, our industry is capitalized, the best in the world, liquidity, best in the world.” Looking ahead to a second Trump administration, when it comes to trimming federal government expenses, Moynihan says, “any enterprise can always be more effectively run,” saying the same cost-cutting measures used in the private sector can be applied to government as well. He also calls for increasing the supply of housing and other commodities that are facing high demand. But despite his past work with President-elect Donald Trump, after his fifteen-year tenure as CEO of the major bank, Moynihan says he feels no need to get involved in politics, feeling he can have as much of an impact in his current role. To see every interview from Yahoo Finance Invest, click here. This post was written by Kayla Hawkins.

headline: BofA CEO urges Trump administration to tackle US budget
summary: Trump's victory in the presidential election has contributed to a sell-off in government bonds in recent days as key elements of his economic plans such as tax cuts and tariffs are expected to lead to faster growth as well as higher inflation and wider budget deficits.  "One thing they have to make sure is that we start to handle the budget better," Moynihan told the Yahoo Finance Invest conference.

headline: BofA Art Market Update Anticipates Buying Opportunities for Collectors This Fall
summary: Newly released Bank of America art market update finds that lower auction estimates, discounts at galleries and the recent interest rate cuts are driving increased participation among collectors heading into marquee events, including the New York fall auctions and Art Basel Miami. The anticipated favorable buying conditions come on the heels of lower-than-expected art sales in the secondary market during the first half of the year – with auction prices coming in only 1% above their aggregated mi
